awd_titl_txt: Exploring boundary conditions on the theory of agreement through the comparative study of African languages
awd_abstract_narration:
The Afranaph Project focuses on the study of anaphora, the linguistic devices that are used to refer back to previously mentioned entities, the antecedents.  Anaphoric dependents like pronouns and reflexives depend for their reference on antecedents in the same sentence or in discourse. The present research project seeks to understand how patterns of agreement between antecedents and dependents are expressed and organized in African languages and what principles underlie those patterns. The distribution of specialized dependent forms and the manner in which they agree with their antecedents vary considerably across languages, but seem to be variants of certain general patterns of locality and sensitivity to syntactic structure that provides clues about the nature of human cognition. The Afranaph Project supports the documentation of minority languages, some of them endangered, thereby contributing to the development of language professionals with stakes in the future of those languages. Afranaph enhances the training of junior scholars and the creation of new international partnerships. It brings together a diverse research community and has seeded collaborations in linguistic research as well as projects (like the Kinande/English Dictionary) designed for use by non-scholarly communities.

How antecedents and dependents agree involves central topics in linguistic theory. Antecedency relations exist in every language and almost all languages show some agreement between antecedents and dependents (e.g., for person, number or gender). Antecedency relations and patterns of agreement are clues to how syntactic structure shapes human cognition. The research expertise developed in anaphora studies will be applied to many new research domains, including the meaning, morphology and syntax of tense and aspect, sentential embedding, noun classes, and agreement. This cross-linguistic investigation adds to the aggregate of information available for each language in the project. The new research is facilitated by the resources of the Afranaph Project, which has developed a research model and infrastructure that permits the discovery, documentation, analysis and explanation of new empirical patterns of interest to linguistic theory and typology. Afranaph employs the expertise of native speakers of African languages who are trained as linguists in order to generate data sets relevant to research questions in theoretical linguistics. Data is elicited with detailed, specially-designed questionnaires, analyzed in collaboration with consultants and then made freely available to any interested party in our online database and website. Newly elicited data on antecedent agreement will be pooled with data previously collected, enriching our database resource for future research on additional topics. A by-product of the funding is support for Afranaph Project infrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the major goals of linguistic research is to understand what sort of mental ability underlies our species specific ability to learn and use the grammars that underlie human languages. Part of this task is to better appreciate the true diversity of human languages. Our study was designed to explore understudied African languages focusing on a ubiquitous property that most human grammars include, namely, agreement phenomena. Agreement phenomena include subject-verb agreement, object-verb agreement, adjective-noun agreement, subject-predicate agreement, and agreement of a pronoun or reflexive with its antecedent (anaphora), among others. The features that agree depend on features of particular languages, including gender (or noun class), number, person, case and sometimes other features that have discourse importance (allocutive agreement, logophoricity). The theoretical question we tried to answer is whether all these forms of agreement are formed by the same mental operation, or whether the systematic differences between kinds of agreement results from different ways they are formed. Our research discovered a number of new constructions where verbs agree with voice that had not been attested before (certain forms of complementizer agreement) and instance of anaphora where no agreement occurs. Our tentative conclusion is that agreement in anaphora relations is not formed by the same mechanism that the other forms of agreement or built by, but our main contribution was to expand the range of empirical patterns that bear on the proper resolution of our research question.

An additional research objective to explore clausal complementation relations led to the discovery of a correlation between “actual clauses”, which function as embedded assertions in those languages that have them, and “narrative tense”, which involves chained sequences of clauses where only the first is tensed and the subsequent clauses tend to describe a sequence of events. Our research found that for at least 8 Eastern Bantu languages that have special morphology for actual clause complements, the same morphology is used for narrative chaining. Afranaph researchers proposed an analysis designed to link the two uses that suggests a new line of research.

Our research spanned more than 15 African languages based on data elicited by the research team in collaboration with linguists who are native speakers of the languages studied. The data collected was integrated with the Afranaph Project database, which, including those 15, contains rich data sets from 40 African languages. All of our data, both static data and our database, are freely accessible from the Afranaph website without any password barrier. Future researchers will be able to use our data to test new ideas or reinterpret the analyses that we have proposed.

In addtion to what is available on our website, our research results have been presented at conferences in Europe, Africa, Asia and North America. Some of our research has been published in conference proceedings and peer-reviewed journals. The grant provided five years of graduate student support for training. All of our native speaker linguist consultants were compensated from the grant as well, which is sometimes a meaningful sum for those residing in African countries (which is most of them). Most of the published papers were collaborations between US-based Afranaph researchers and native-speaker linguist consultants. Three dissertations based on Afranaph data were begun or completed at Rutgers University, the host of the Afranaph Project, during the grant period.
